title: Exploring numerical data
text:
Scatterplots
Compare two numerical variables

title: Exploring numerical data
text:
Dot Plot
Visualize the distribution of one numerical variable

ggplot(data = penguins, 
       mapping = aes(x = flipper_length_mm)) +
  geom_dotplot(dotsize=0.75, binwidth=1)

title: Exploring numerical data
text:
Mean (average) flipper length?

mean(penguins$flipper_length_mm, na.rm = TRUE)

[1] 200.9152





penguins |>
  summarize( mean = mean(flipper_length_mm, na.rm = TRUE))

# A tibble: 1 × 1
   mean
  <dbl>
1  201.

title: Exploring numerical data
text:
Visualize the Mean
A measure of center of a distribution.

title: Exploring numerical data
text:
Calculuating the Mean
Sample mean \(\overline{x}\)
\[
\overline{x} = \frac{ x_1 + x_2 + x_3 + \ldots + x_n}{n}
\]


Population mean \(\mu\) (Greek letter “mu”) \[
\overline{x} \approx \mu
\]

Question: what is the average age of the people in this room?

title: Exploring numerical data
text:
Histogram

ggplot(data = penguins, 
       mapping = aes(x = flipper_length_mm)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 5, color="white" )








This distribution is bimodal and right skewed

title: Exploring numerical data
text:
Body Mass

ggplot(data = penguins, 
       mapping = aes(x = body_mass_g)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 250, col="white")








This distribution is unimodal and right skewed

title: Exploring numerical data
text:
Bill Depth

ggplot(data = penguins, 
       mapping = aes(x = bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 0.5, col="white")








This distribution is bimodal and right skewed

title: Exploring numerical data
text:
Mean (average) Body Temperature
What do you think it is?

title: Exploring numerical data
text:
Mean (average) Body Temperature

mean(thermometry$body.temp)

[1] 98.24923

title: Exploring numerical data
text:
Variance
Measure of variation or how spread out distribution is. It’s the average squared distance from the mean.
Sample variance is \(s^2\)
where s is the sample standard deviation \[
s = \sqrt{ \frac{ \sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \overline{x})^2 }{n-1}}
\]



Population variance: \(\sigma^2\) (Greek letter “sigma”)

title: Exploring numerical data
text:
Standard Deviation
s is the sample standard deviation. Represents the typical deviation from the mean \[
s = \sqrt{ \frac{ \sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \overline{x})^2 }{n-1}}
\]

Empirical Rule
Typically, about 68% of the data (observations) lie within one s.d. of the mean.
About 98% of the data lie within two s.d. of the mean.
These percentages are not hard and fast rules!

title: Exploring numerical data
text:
Body Temperature

thermometry |>
   summarize( mean = mean(body.temp), sd = sd(body.temp))

      mean        sd
1 98.24923 0.7331832


Using the empirical rule, about 68% of observations lie in what range of temperatures?

title: Exploring numerical data
text:
IQR

summary(thermometry$body.temp)

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
  96.30   97.80   98.30   98.25   98.70  100.80

title: Linear Regression
text:
Practice from last time: 7.5 (3, 7, 9, 19)

title: Linear Regression
text:
Practice from last time: 7.5 (3, 7, 9, 19)

Practice for next time: 7.5 ()

title: Linear Regression
text:
Associations between two numerical variables

Explanatory variable: \(x\), independent (a variable you think might be related to response )
Response variable: \(y\), dependent (a variable you want to understand)

title: Linear Regression
text:
Possums: `tail_l’ vs ‘total_l’
Do possums’ tail length and total body length seem to be associated? Might knowing one help us predict the other?

ggplot(data = possum, aes(y = total_l, x = tail_l)) +
  geom_point() +
   labs(x = "Length of Possum Tail (cm)",
       y = "Length of Possum Body (cm)")

title: Linear Regression
text:
Linear model: “line of best fit”

ggplot(data = possum, aes(y = total_l, x = tail_l)) +
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Linear Regression
text:
Finding the “least squares” regression line
Recall: a line has the equation \[ y=mx+b\] where \(m\) = slope and \(b\) = \(y\)-intercept. Here, we want a line of the form
\[ \textrm{Total body length} = b_0 + b_1 \cdot \textrm{(Tail length)} \]
How could you use this line to predict the total body length of a possum with tail 41.6 cm long?

title: Linear Regression
text:
Properties
The least squares regression line has the following properties:

Minimizes (sum of squared) distance between data points and line
The residuals balance out above and below line
The point \((\bar{x}, \bar{y})\) always lies on line (though it’s not necessarily a data point!)

title: Linear Regression
text:
Correlation coefficient, r
Also called the Pearson Product-Moment Correlation, here’s how r is calculated: \[ r(x,y) = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n} (x_i-\bar{x})(y_i-\bar{y})}{\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x})^2 \cdot\sum_{i=1}^{n}(y_i-\bar{y})^2 }}\] This is a good computation to have R do for us!

title: Linear Regression
text:
Correlation coefficient, r

possum |>
  summarize(N = n(), 
      r = cor(tail_l, total_l, 
              use = "pairwise.complete.obs"))

# A tibble: 1 × 2
      N     r
  <int> <dbl>
1   104 0.566


What does this number mean?

title: Linear Regression
text:
Visualizing the correlation coefficient, r





What would a correlation of \(r = -0.998\) look like? How about \(r=1\)?

title: Linear Regression
text:
Finding the “least squares” regression line
\[ y = b_0 + b_1 \cdot x \] First we find the slope: \[b_1 = r \left( \frac{s_y}{s_x} \right)\]
where:

\(r\) = correlation coefficient
\(s_y\) = standard deviation of \(y\)
\(s_x\) = standard deviation of \(x\)

Next we use the fact that \((\bar{x}, \bar{y})\) lies on our line to solve for the intercept, \(b_0\):
\[\bar{y} = b_0 + b_1 \cdot \bar{x} \]

title: Linear Regression
text:
Example (continued)
To model the association between tail_l and total_l, we need summary statistics to find the slope and intercept of the linear regression:

possum |>
  summarize( 
    mean_x = mean(tail_l),
    sd_x = sd(tail_l),
    mean_y = mean(total_l),
    sd_y = sd(total_l),
    r = cor(tail_l, total_l)
    )

# A tibble: 1 × 5
  mean_x  sd_x mean_y  sd_y     r
   <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
1   37.0  1.96   87.1  4.31 0.566


What line does this produce?

title: Linear Regression
text:
Example: Possum regression line
First, find the slope:
\[
b_1 = r \cdot \left( \frac{s_y}{s_x} \right) = .566 \left( \frac{4.31}{1.96} \right) = 1.24
\] Next, use \((\bar{x}, \bar{y})\) to find the intercept: \[
\bar{y} = b_0 + b_1 \cdot \bar{x}  \quad \implies \quad 87.1 = b_0 + 1.24(37.0)  
\]
\[
\implies  b_0 = 87.1 - 1.24 (37.0) = 41.2
\]
Thus: \(y = 41.2 + 1.24 x\) is the linear model describing these two possum variables.

title: Linear Regression
text:
Example: Possum regression line
\[
y = 41.2 + 1.24 x
\]


`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Linear Regression
text:
Example: Possum regression line
Alternately, we can find the entire linear model in one go:

library(tidymodels)


 model_fit <- linear_reg() |>
      fit(total_l ~ tail_l, data = possum)
 
tidy(model_fit)

# A tibble: 2 × 5
  term        estimate std.error statistic  p.value
  <chr>          <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>    <dbl>
1 (Intercept)    41.0      6.66       6.16 1.43e- 8
2 tail_l          1.24     0.180      6.93 3.94e-10



What does the intercept (41) mean?

What does the slope (1.24) tell us?

title: Linear Regression

title: MTH161 :: Elementary Statistics  Fall 2024
text:
Welcome!

I am looking forward to working with each of you this semester! It is my top priority to support your growth as a learner and to make our time together both in class and out productive and engaging. I will strive to create an learning environment where all of our different perspectives and identities are valued and respected, where the contributions of every person are celebrated, and where you feel comfortable fully engaging in class.
While I’ll do everything in my power to support you, your success in this course ultimately depends on you. I ask you to bring a readiness to work and a belief that you can learn. I absolutely believe this about each of you. I will also ask you to do tasks that are just at the edge of what you can handle because that is how the best learning happens, but if you are prepared to invest your time and energy, and to communicate with me about how you’re doing, I can and will support you.
As we work together this semester, your suggestions are encouraged and appreciated. Please let me know ways to improve the effectiveness of the course for you personally, or for other students or student groups. In particular, if you ever feel like your experience in this class is being impacted by your experiences outside of class, please don’t hesitate to come and talk with me. If you prefer to speak with someone outside of the class, your academic deans are an excellent resource.

title: Decision Errors
text:
Hypothesis Testing Framework




State the null hypothesis and the alternative hypothesis



Choose a sample, collect and analyze the data




How likely is it to see data like what we observed, if the null hypothesis were true?




If very unlikely, we reject the null hypothesis. Otherwise, we cannot reject the null claim.

title: Decision Errors
text:
Making a decision
If the conditional probability of obtaining our test statistic, or more extreme, is very small: \[
p < \alpha
\] We have evidence to reject the null hypothesis.
This probability is the p-value and the discernment level (\(\alpha\)) (or significance level) is our threshold for “very small”.

title: Decision Errors
text:
Making a decision
On the other hand, if the p-value is greater (or equal to) \(\alpha\), we say the results are not statistically significant and we fail to reject.


Note: we don’t say \(H_0\) is true – just that we don’t have evidence to say it’s not!

title: Decision Errors
text:
Choosing a discernability level
This should always be done before seeing the data!

What are the consequences of making an incorrect decision?

title: Decision Errors
text:
Type I Error
Suppose that the null hypothesis is actually true



we might correcly fail to reject (good decision)
we might incorrectly reject the null hypothesis

title: Decision Errors
text:
Type II Error
Suppose that the null hypothesis is actually not true



we might correcly reject (good decision)
we might incorrectly fail to reject the null hypothesis

title: Decision Errors
text:
Decision Errors


Suppose the null hypothesis is \(H_0\)

Type I Error: rejecting \(H_0\) when it is actually true
Type II Error: not rejecting \(H_0\) when it is actually false

How likely these errors are depends on discernment level.
What are the consequences for making each type of error?
Choose \(\alpha\) accordingly!

title: Decision Errors
text:
Example


A researcher believes that the mean number of pesticides is higher in the Willamette river than compared to a 1996 report that cited 36 different pesticides. The researcher collects samples from the river over a year’s time and found a significant increase in the mean number of pesticides.




State the null and alternative hypotheses.
What has happened if a type I error occurs – what are the potential consequences?
What has happened if a type II error occurs – what are the potential consequences?

title: Decision Errors
text:
Controlling for Errors

To avoid Type I errors, make it harder to reject \(H_0\) – make discernment level smaller
To avoid Type II errors, make it easier to reject \(H_0\) – make discernment level bigger

title: Decision Errors
text:
For Thursday…

Read about one-sided and two-side tests
